ygData.subject: RE: Re: Ideas for Womens Guild
ygData.msgSnippet: I ve started a couple of characters on Brell (I like the idea of being on an RP server independent of the guild).  So far I m not sure what I have would fit in
ygData.messageBody:
I've started a couple of characters on Brell (I like the idea of being on an
RP server independent of the guild). So far I'm not sure what I have would
fit in with a "Sisters of Erollisi" concept. Though female .. none are
"love" oriented, though only one is truely evil.

I should be able to be in the chat tonight ... perhaps when I see the mix
of other races/classes I'll come up with something to compliment that will
fit. But I do wonder how we will manage a bunch of "Sisters of Love" ;P I
also have disagreement with how EQ set up the current Sisters from an RP
angle (well said already), but I don't want to inherit that confusion.
While I like the structure of the guild proposed ... would it be possible
to be Sisters of {Something Else}? Then we could set up our own RP angle
without confusion with an existing NPC order? I also think harassment
from non-RPing males may be enhanced if our charter mentions the
(non-chaste Sisters of Love), since as already said, historically that
meant public sex, or prostitution, usually religiously done in the name of
fertility. As well, the NPC sisters are wood elf warriors who follow
Erollisi, interestingly not a PC option. And another RP oddity I noticed
... the Marr twins created Barbarians, and planted "the seed" from which
humans evolved from Barbarians, however Barbarians cannot worship the
Marr's, though most humans can. (Sorry, a good friend of mine was in
charge of "consistency" for many plays ... she got me in the habit of
spotting these little odd things). I just think EQ didn't think the
existing sisters out as well as Christina Norman did :P .

Tunare is the only other female godess ...
or what do we stand for? Love? Goodness? Comraderie? Valor? Triumph?

- Lora
"The female is always the more deadly ..."

BTW, the chastity thing comes from Roman warrior's beliefs. And it only
applied to MALES. Though the commanders were probably correct in the
belief. Chaste warriors had nothing to come home to so *should* on average
fight more valiantly than one who wanted to live to see his child born :)
The concept spread through Europe and the knighthoods due to early Roman
cultural influences and the fact that "adapting" it to a religious
requirement of knighthood gave the early Christian Church as stronger basis
in the military (a must for political survival). But mixing this with a
bunch or warriors of love?
